docs.snippet: FROM an Argentine point of view, prices in this country look stable and development opportunities in Manhattan are promising. Which explains why Jacobo  Finkielstain is undertaking commercial development here.         He has purchased the...
docs.lead_paragraph: FROM an Argentine point of view, prices in this country look stable and development opportunities in Manhattan are promising. Which explains why Jacobo Finkielstain is undertaking commercial development here. He has purchased the 26,500-square-foot construction site on the west side of Third Avenue between 54th Street and 55th Street from the Minskoff Organization, and plans to put up a modest-sized office building of about 450,000 square feet of space on perhaps 36 or 38 floors. The hope is to have it ready for occupancy in 1983.

docs.snippet: The Court of Appeals, New York's highest judicial body, today upheld the conviction of Dr. Mark Gerard, a Long Island veterinarian found guilty of fraud  in a horse-switching incident at Belmont Park in 1977.         The court handed down a unanimous...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Court of Appeals, New York's highest judicial body, today upheld the conviction of Dr. Mark Gerard, a Long Island veterinarian found guilty of fraud in a horse-switching incident at Belmont Park in 1977. The court handed down a unanimous decision against Dr. Gerard, who has been sentenced to one year in prison and a $1,000 fine. Dr. Gerard, a specialist in the care of race horses, had been found guilty in State Supreme Court of ''fraudulent entries and practices in contests of speed'' over the switching of a speedy horse from Uruguay named Cinzano, worth $150,000, for a horse name Lebon, worth $450. The conviction was subsequently upheld in the Appellate Division of Supreme Court.

headline.main: Horse-Switching Verdict Upheld by Appeals Court

docs.snippet: The global population explosion is losing some of its force, a new United Nations . report says, but the biggest gains are taking place in the poorest nations and threatening new misery.         By the end of the century the pace of population growth...
docs.lead_paragraph: The global population explosion is losing some of its force, a new United Nations . report says, but the biggest gains are taking place in the poorest nations and threatening new misery. By the end of the century the pace of population growth is expected to fall by 20 percent, to 16 births per thousand a year, compared with 20 per thousand now. This will still mean a rise in world population from 4.4 billion to 6.2 billion, causing ''explosive growth'' in the already overcrowded cities of the third world.

headline.main: WORLD POPULATION EXPLOSION IS SLOWING, U.N. FINDS

docs.snippet: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14-- The global population explosion is losing some of its force, a new United Nations report says, but the biggest gains are taking place in the poorest nations and threatening new misery.
docs.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14-- The global population explosion is losing some of its force, a new United Nations report says, but the biggest gains are taking place in the poorest nations and threatening new misery.
docs.abstract: Annual report by UN Fund for Population Activities finds global population explosion is losing some of its force but that biggest gains are taking place in poorest nations and threatening new misery; report, written by agency's executive director Rafael M Salas, holds there may be explosive growth in already-crowded Third World cities by end of 20th century, because of expected rise in world population from 4.4 billion to 6.2 billion; other findings; graph compares current population of world's 15 largest metropolitan areas with that predicted by year 2000 (M)

headline.main: World Population Explosion Is Slowing, U.N. Finds; Long-Range Hazards Unprecedented Growth in Cities
